title-group.article-title: A generalized renormalization group turbulence model and its application to a light-duty diesel engine operating in a low-temperature combustion regime

article-meta.aff: 1Research Center for Advanced Powertrain Technology, Hunan University, Changsha, China
2Engine Research Center, University of Wisconsin–Madison, Madison, WI, USA
3Combustion Research Facility, Sandia National Laboratories, Livermore, CA, USA

author-notes.corresp: Rolf D Reitz, Engine Research Center, University of Wisconsin–Madison, 1500 Engineering Drive, Rm 1018A, Madison, WI 53706, USA. Email: reitz@engr.wisc.edu

abstract.p: A generalized renormalization group closure model based on the “dimensionality” of the flow strain rate is proposed and applied to engine flows in this study. In the model, the model coefficients C1, C2, and C3 are constructed as functions of the flow strain rate. Computations were made for compressing/expanding flows in a diesel engine under motoring conditions. It was found that the generalized renormalization group model performs better than the standard renormalization group k−ε model in terms of its predictions of turbulent kinetic energy and model length scales. Computations in a diesel engine operating under low-temperature combustion conditions were also investigated to further assess the performance of the present model. Predictions of the spatial distributions of unburned hydrocarbons were significantly improved and agreed well with available experimental images. Engine-out unburned hydrocarbon emission was predicted to be smaller with the generalized renormalization group model than with the standard renormalization group k−ε model.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Numerical simulation of the mixture formation and combustion processes in internal combustion (IC) engines is rapidly being accepted as a useful tool for engine design and optimization. However, despite continued advances in computing power, the computational cost is still very high using state-of-the-art large eddy simulation (LES) techniques, although they offer advantages for engine simulations, such as higher fidelity predictions, and the ability to resolve cycle-to-cycle variations in flow structure and combustion behavior compared to Reynolds-averaged Navier–Stokes (RANS) models. Considering the numerous iterations needed to achieve an optimal engine design, together with the many operating parameters that need to be considered—such as engine speed, load, intake conditions, and geometry—simulations based on the more computationally efficient RANS approach are likely to remain the dominant method for simulating engine flows for the next decade. Thus, improving the accuracy of flow predictions made using the relatively inexpensive RANS engineering turbulence models is of great practical importance.

Among the RANS-based models, the two-equation k−ε model is the most widely used. Despite over three decades of use, the ability of these approaches to model the impact of bulk flow compression has not yet been satisfactorily resolved.1–4 Specifically, the modeling of the dissipation of turbulent kinetic energy, when the coefficients of the modeled equation are optimized for the compression process, leads to an unrealistic growth of the turbulent time and length scales during expansion.3,4

One potential approach to resolving this problem is to employ model coefficients that vary with the characteristic strain rate (or turbulent-to-mean time scale ratio) of the flow. Dissipation equation closures based on such analysis are one example of these closures.5–9 In this study, a generalized renormalization group (RNG) closure model based on the “dimensionality” of the flow strain rate is suggested to improve the predictions of turbulence quantities. The model coefficients C1, C2, and C3 are all functions of the flow strain rate in this modeling. To test the performance of the proposed generalized RNG closure model, in-cylinder nonreacting engine flows were computed during the compression and expansion processes, and the calculated turbulence quantities were compared with available experimental data in the same engine.

The performance of turbulence models for engine combustion predictions is also of much practical interest. During the past years, work has been done to construct useful models for diesel engines by employing state-of-the-art submodels that feature consideration of detailed chemical kinetics.10–13 Although much progress has been made, some combustion characteristics are still not predicted satisfactorily.14–16 Since the thermal field is strongly coupled with the flow dynamics in IC engine, it is believed that turbulence modeling plays an important role in engine combustion prediction.

In order to examine the influence of the turbulence model, in this study, the generalized RNG model was also applied to combustion computations in a light-duty diesel engine operating in a low-temperature combustion (LTC) condition. The computed cylinder pressure, heat release rate (HRR), cylinder temperature, mixture fraction as well as the spatial distribution of the unburned hydrocarbon (UHC) emissions were compared with results obtained using the standard RNG k−ε model introduced by Han and Reitz.9 A comparison was also conducted between the predictions and measurements15,16 of in-cylinder UHC spatial distributions, and the new model is seen to provide improved predictions. Details of the proposed closure model are described next, followed by the model validation against experiments.

sec.title: The k–ε model
sec.p: The “standard”k−ε model applied to a compressible turbulent flow is generally given as

The other model coefficients C1 and C2 are found by requiring that equation (2) duplicates measured behavior in homogeneous shear flows and decaying grid turbulence, respectively.17 For flows with bulk compression, C3 in equation (2) is typically determined from a rapid distortion analysis.18 A review of various proposals for C3 is provided by Wu et al.2 and Miles et al.3

sec.title: Closure model based on the RNG methodology
sec.p: The RNG analysis5–7 contrives to remove the impact of small-scale flow structures on the larger scales by successively averaging the equations of motion over infinitesimal bands of small scales and collecting the effect of this scale removal process in a modified viscosity. The method allows the derivation of the k and ε equations, including providing numerical values for the coefficients Cµ, C1, and C2. In the ε equation, an additional term R, which is neither present in the standard equation nor closed by the RNG analysis, is found. Yakhot et al.8 model R as

where

Compressibility was not accounted for in the RNG analysis. Consequently, Han and Reitz9 introduced a modification to the RNG ε equation by adding a term,

Equation (7) is identical to the expression obtained by Coleman and Mansour,18 with the exception of the last term on the RHS. This additional term abruptly changes sign depending on the sign of the mean velocity field divergence. Note that the additional term is not dependent on the characteristic strain rate.
For compressible flows, the closure model based on the RNG methodology (hereafter called standard RNG k−ε model) is obtained by retaining R in the form given by equation (5)

For isentropic compression of a fluid with a specific heat ratio, γ or µ0, which is dependent on Tm, where T denotes temperature, the contribution to C3 due to viscosity change (i.e. the second term on the RHS of equation(7)) is approximated with γ = 1.4 and m = 0.5 as

sec.title: Development of a generalized RNG turbulence model
sec.p: An improved RANS turbulence model based on a generalized RNG closure is derived in this section. In this modeling approach, the model coefficients C1, C2, and C3 are all constructed to be functions of the local flow strain rate. This methodology is justified by the results of Direct Numerical Stimulation (DNS) analysis, as reported in a previous study.19

As mentioned above, the value of C3 was derived for the special case of rapid spherical compression. However, spherical compression is a very specific flow condition, which is far from general turbulent flows. For example, piston motion in an IC engine leads to two other special cases of pure compression: one-dimensional (1D) unidirectional axial compression as well as two-dimensional (2D) cylindrical–radial compression (squish). It is therefore of interest to also explore these two types of compressions and further general cases of pure compression. As proposed in previous works,1,20,21 for a general rapid compression at low Mach number, the evolution of the turbulence can be described by the following equations

Equation (11) embodies the physical constraint that keeps
ρ

The RNG ε-equation (8) can be applied to this flow as well. Under a general compression, the mean strain tensor may be written as

In equations (15) and (16), the suggested “dimensionality”a and n of the strain rate field are calculated to be 2.0 and 1.0 for unidirectional 1D compression, 0.5 and 2.0 for cylindrical–radial 2D compression, and 0.0 and 3.0 for spherical 3D compression, respectively.

Consistent with k−ε modeling theory, assuming that the sum (Gk) of the production and dissipation of turbulent kinetic energy (k) is proportional to the sum (Gε) of the production and dissipation of the dissipate rate of turbulent kinetic energy (ε), that is
Therefore
Under the general compression condition, the production P can be substituted by equation (13), and then equation (23) can be rewritten as

caption.p: Turbulence model coefficients.

fn.p: RNG: renormalization group; G-RNG: generalized version of the RNG.

sec.p: Since the low-Reynolds-number modifications are also given by the RNG theory,5 wall functions are not necessarily required. However, this approach would require fine meshes, and such fine meshes are not practical for engine modeling. Previous studies, for example, a computation of Reitz22 in a pancake-combustion-chamber engine, indicated that the use of wall function with compressibility and unsteadiness modifications could also give fairly good predictions of wall heat transfer with affordable grid sizes for engineering computations. Therefore, the traditional wall function approach was chosen for calculation of the near-wall turbulence and heat transfer. It is assumed that turbulence production is equal to turbulence dissipation in the log layer of a turbulent boundary layer.23 The boundary conditions for k and ε are
where n is the unit normal to the wall, κ is the Von Karman constant with a value of 0.4,23 and y is the physical distance from the nearest wall.

sec.title: Computation of engine compressing and expanding flows
sec.p: As discussed above, the modeling approach of the proposed G-RNG closure model is supported by the DNS analysis in a previous study.19 Furthermore, the G-RNG closure model was applied to the compressible jet flows, and predicted jet tip penetrations were improved significantly and agreed well with the measurements.19 In this section, computations of compressing and expanding flows in an engine are conducted to further test the G-RNG closure model.

sec.title: Computation setup and comparison with experiment
sec.p: The methodology for estimating k and ε experimentally relies on the determination of the temporal evolution of k and on estimation of P, derived from both the experimental data and numerical simulation. The integral length scale is estimated through transformations of measured temporal autocorrelation functions into a spatial domain by application of Taylor’s hypothesis. Details are given in the studies by Miles et al.3,4,24 and Miles.25

Measurements were done using a two-component laser Doppler velocimeter (LDV) to simultaneously measure the tangential and radial components of the velocity in the swirl-supported diesel engine shown in Figure 1. Details of the measurement locations (with the piston depicted at top dead center (TDC)), the bowl geometry, and the coordinate system employed are also shown in Figure 1. The measurements were made in clusters, centered at the same radial coordinate r = 13.6 mm at various axial distances below the cylinder head (Z = 4, 8, and 12 mm). The mean velocity gradients in the axial and radial directions can be determined directly from the measurements. Gradients in the tangential direction are assumed to be zero in this axisymmetric, motored flow. The remaining, unmeasured gradients are deduced from application of the continuity equation
( ∂
u
z
/
∂ z )
and multidimensional simulation
( ∂
u
z
/
∂ r )
.

caption.p: (a) Schematic of optical engine and experimental configuration (LDV system) and (b) coordinate system and locations of measurement clusters.3,4
LDV: Laser Doppler Velocimeter.

sec.p: The engine geometry considered is typical of high-speed automotive direct injection diesel engines. Relevant details regarding the geometry and operating conditions are summarized in Table 2. The computations were performed using the KIVA-3V code23 with the G-RNG model implemented. The computations started from 55° before top dead center (BTDC), where the initial pressure and temperature were 7.5 bar and 578K, respectively, and the effects of compression began to significantly influence the flows generated by the intake process. The initial k and ε were modeled from the measurements.3,4 The tangential mean velocities were initialized at 55° BTDC to a solid body–like radial velocity profile at the specified swirl ratio by setting the KIVA variable “swipro” to 2.2. A structured mesh with 53,490 cells was created to capture the bowl geometry. A schematic of the mesh at 40° BTDC is shown in Figure 2. The mesh has been shown to provide mesh-independent results and has been used in previous studies.3,4

caption.p: Engine specifications and operating conditions (motoring conditions).
Piston bowl sector mesh with engine at 40° BTDC.

sec.title: Dimensionality analysis of engine flow
sec.p: The computations spanned from 55° BTDC to 55° after top dead center (ATDC). Hence, flows under both compression and expansion conditions are considered. Before comparing the predictions of turbulence quantities, the calculated magnitudes of the normal components of the flow strain rate tensor were analyzed to check the compression type of the flows. Three locations, near the bowl lip (Z = 4 mm), at a mid-location (Z = 8 mm) in the bowl, and deep in the bowl (Z = 12 mm) at a higher swirl ratio (Rs = 3.5), were selected and are shown in Figure 3.

caption.p: Calculated normal components of mean strain rate as a function of CAD for the high swirl ratio condition (Rs = 3.5) at three locations: (a) Z = 4 mm, (b) Z = 8 mm, and (c) Z = 12 mm.
CAD: crank angle degrees; ATDC: after top dead center.

sec.p: As discussed in the previous section, for a spherical compression case, the magnitude of the strain rate components S11, S22, and S33 would be equivalent. However, as seen in Figure 3, the normal components of the strain rate tensor S11, S22, and S33 at the three locations are all seen to be very different. In Figure 4, the calculated average “dimensionality”n of the flow strain rate is about 2.2, which means that the strain rate field is not in the spherical compression condition. Actually, the compression type is closer to a 2D cylindrical–radial compression. Thus, the present G-RNG closure model is more suitable for the current engine flow. The same trend was also seen for the other swirl ratio conditions.

caption.p: Calculated “dimensionality”n of strain rate field in the motored engine flow.
CAD: crank angle degrees; ATDC: after top dead center.

sec.p: Figure 5 shows contour plots of n in the engine flows in the midplane of the mesh during the compression and expansion strokes. At 40° BTDC, 1D unidirectional compression is seen to be dominant in the bowl (blue color). As time proceeds, the 1D compression region almost vanishes, and 2D compression occupies almost all the combustion chamber at TDC. After TDC, three-dimensional (3D) spherical compression patterns are generated, and the compression type becomes nearly 3D, as seen particularly in the bowl region (purple color) at 5° ATDC and at 10° ATDC. The averaged development process of n in the cylinder flow is consistent with the analysis of the three different locations shown in Figure 4.

caption.p: Spatial distributions of calculated “dimensionality” at different crank angles. The blue, green, and purple colors represent the 1D unidirectional, 2D cylindrical–radial, and 3D spherical compression conditions, respectively.
CAD: crank angle degrees; ATDC: after top dead center.

sec.title: Predictions of turbulence quantities
sec.p: Two different turbulence models were applied to the same engine flow: the present G-RNG turbulence model and the standard RNG k−ε model. Predictions of k, ε, and the model-predicted length scale are compared in Figure 6. The left-hand column presents turbulence parameters for the modest swirl ratio case (Rs = 2.5) deep in the bowl (Z = 12 mm), where the impact of velocity gradients caused by the squish flow is small, and the right-hand column shows results obtained for a higher swirl ratio (Rs = 3.5) near the bowl lip (Z = 4 mm), where the squish-induced velocity gradients are large.

caption.p: Predicted turbulence kinetic energy, dissipation rate, and model length scales. (a) The left-hand column presents the modest swirl ratio case (Rs = 2.5) deep in the bowl (Z = 12 mm) and (b) the right-hand column presents a higher swirl ratio (Rs = 3.5) near the bowl lip (Z = 4 mm).
CAD: crank angle degrees; ATDC: after top dead center; RNG: renormalization group; G-RNG: generalized version of the RNG.

sec.p: For both cases, it can be seen that the predicted k of G-RNG model during the compression stroke agrees better than that of the standard RNG model when compared with the measurements. However, the improvement during expansion stroke is relatively small. This is because, during expansion stroke, more 3D spherical compression regions appear as noted above, and the standard RNG model was developed under the spherical compression assumption. Since the RNG turbulence models are not sufficiently dissipative, as supported by the results of DNS analysis reported in the above section, the predictions of ε were not improved much, but small improvements are seen during the expansion stroke.

However, significant improvement is seen in the predictions of the model length scale with the G-RNG model, and the trends are very close to the measurements, which show a modest decrease during compression and then a slight increase beyond approximately 20° ATDC. Although the magnitudes of the model length scales are larger than the measured data, it is very encouraging to see the G-RNG model that gives a correct trend over the standard RNG model. This is consistent with previous research,1,26 which argued that an increase in integral length scale during the compression stroke is not physically plausible, based on the argument that the integral length scale should be scaled by the compressed volume.

Similar results were found for the other swirl ratio conditions. Thus, it is concluded that the present G-RNG closure model performs better than the standard RNG closure model. However, it should be noted that it is possible that the results are influenced somewhat by the initialization of the turbulence parameters, and this needs to be further assessed in future studies.

sec.title: Application to diesel combustion
sec.p: Flows with spray and combustion are much more complicated than the nonreacting flows discussed above. In the engine combustion case, the thermal field is strongly coupled with the flow dynamics, and the flow turbulence plays an important role in combustion processes in engines. Accordingly, the performance of the G-RNG turbulence model was examined in a light-duty diesel engine undergoing dilution-controlled LTC. The combustion computations were compared with available experimental data15,16 and with results predicted by the standard RNG k−ε model.

sec.title: Multidimensional simulation conditions
sec.p: The engine specifications and operating conditions are summarized in Table 3. The computations span from 144° BTDC to 136° ATDC. To improve computational efficiency, a sector mesh was employed encompassing 1/7 of the combustion chamber, as shown in Figure 7. The number of cells was 39,733 at bottom dead center (BDC), which has been validated and used in previous studies (e.g. Ekoto et al.15 and Sauter et al.27).

caption.p: Engine specifications and operating conditions (firing conditions).
Computational sector mesh of one-seventh of the engine cylinder at compression TDC.

sec.p: For the computational fluid dynamics (CFD) calculations, the KIVA-3V code23 coupled with updated submodels was used. In particular, the Kelvin–Helmholtz/Rayleigh–Taylor (KH/RT) spray atomization and breakup model11 and an improved gas-jet spray model13 were employed in order to reduce mesh size dependency effects. Reactions were simulated using the CHEMKIN chemistry solver,28 assuming locally homogeneous mixture conditions (i.e. well-stirred reactor) in each computational cell. This assumption is particularly suitable for the present well-mixed LTC conditions. To achieve manageable computational times, a reduced chemical reaction mechanism with 39 species and 131 reactions12 was used. The mechanism was developed for diesel fuel surrogates as a primary reference fuel (PRF) mechanism, and n-heptane was selected as the surrogate fuel in this study.

sec.title: Models validation
sec.p: In Figure 8, the calculated in-cylinder pressure profiles are compared with the experimental data. The excellent agreement confirms that the initial and the boundary conditions and model constants are well defined. The main ignition timing is slightly retarded with the standard RNG model, which can be explained by considering the turbulent viscosity, as discussed later.

caption.p: Comparison of pressure profiles for the experiments and calculations of the G-RNG and standard RNG turbulence models.
CAD: crank angle degrees; ATDC: after top dead center; RNG: renormalization group; G-RNG: generalized version of the RNG.

sec.p: The calculated “dimensionality”n of the engine flow field is shown in Figure 9. In order to reveal more details in the various spatial regions in the combustion chamber, the whole chamber (i.e. the bulk region (BK)) was divided into four subregions: bowl region (BW), above bowl region (AB), squish region (SQ), and crevice region (CRV), as seen in Figure 10. It is seen that n in the three regions has a similar value ranging between 1.5 and 2.5 during the compression and expansion strokes. Considering that the standard RNG model assumes n = 3 all the time, the G-RNG closure model better captures the features of the engine flow field.

caption.p: Calculated “dimensionality” of strain rate field in different regions of the engine combustion chamber.
BK: bulk-averaged; BW: bowl region; SQ: squish region; CAD: crank angle degrees; ATDC: after top dead center.
Schematic of engine combustion chamber regions.
BW: bowl region; AB: above bowl region; SQ: squish region; CRV: crevice region.

sec.p: The calculated turbulence viscosity νt and the spatial root mean square (RMS) of the mixture fractions in the engine are plotted in Figure 11. Mixture fraction RMS is an indicator of the mixture homogeneity (in space), and its fast decay indicates enhanced mixing. The viscosity calculated by the G-RNG model is seen to decrease until around 15° ATDC, and then it increases during the later stages of combustion, which results in fast decay of the mixture fraction RMS, as shown in Figure 11. Therefore, a more homogenous mixture is obtained. The viscosity predicted by the standard RNG model remains fairly constant at a lower level during the expansion stroke, which leads to a slower decay of the mixture fraction RMS. In general, a large discrepancy in the turbulence viscosity is seen between the G-RNG and standard RNG models during the compression stroke, while the discrepancy decreases significantly during the expansion stroke. This can be explained again by considering the calculated flow “dimensionality”n shown in Figure 9. When n is closer to 3 (i.e. the spherical compression condition), the difference in the predicted turbulence field becomes less and so do differences in the turbulent viscosity.

caption.p: Profiles of bulk-averaged mixture fraction RMS (right-hand side) and turbulence viscosity calculated by the G-RNG and standard RNG turbulence models.
CAD: crank angle degrees; ATDC: after top dead center; RMS: root mean square; RNG: renormalization group; G-RNG: generalized version of the RNG.

sec.p: In the current CFD code, turbulent transport (i.e. turbulent diffusion) is modeled assuming a linear relationship between the turbulence diffusivity, D, and the turbulent viscosity νt (i.e. turbulent Schmidt number, Sc = νt/D). During the early stages of combustion, the decreased turbulent diffusivity, D, due to lower turbulent viscosity calculated by G-RNG model (relative to the standard RNG model), leads to a slower decay of mixture fraction RMS in the engine, as shown in Figure 11. The less homogeneous species mixture condition leads to decreased rate of heat release and cumulative heat release, as plotted in Figure 12, and consequently to lower temperatures, as shown in Figure 13.

caption.p: HRR and AHR (right-hand side) profiles calculated by the G-RNG and standard RNG turbulence models as a function of CAD.
CAD: crank angle degrees; ATDC: after top dead center; RNG: renormalization group; G-RNG: generalized version of the RNG; HRR: heat release rate; AHR: accumulative heat release.
Comparison of averaged cylinder temperature predicted by the G-RNG and standard RNG models.
CAD: crank angle degrees; ATDC: after top dead center; RNG: renormalization group; G-RNG: generalized version of the RNG.

sec.p: During the later stage of combustion, a different trend in the mixture fraction RMS is seen (Figure 11). Increased turbulent diffusivity is predicted by the G-RNG model due to the higher turbulent viscosity, which leads to the faster decay of the mixture fraction RMS. A more homogeneous mixture is obtained, which results in a higher rate of heat release, as shown in Figure 12, and therefore, higher cylinder temperatures, as shown in Figure 13.

The UHC emissions are an indicator of fuel–air mixing. In Figure 14, the evolution of UHC mass divided by the injected fuel mass is compared for the two turbulence models. Since fuel is also included in the UHC amount, the early rise represents injected fuel. Approaching the peak, the predicted UHC is slightly lower with the G-RNG model. This is consistent with the faster HRR (i.e. shorter ignition delay), as shown in Figure 12. After the peak, UHC is oxidized quickly in both cases, but it is stabilized at a lower level with the G-RNG model. This is due to the less homogeneous mixture condition (Figure 11), which results in slower combustion and allows further oxidation of UHC in the expansion stroke (Figure 12).

caption.p: Temporal evolution of predicted UHC as a function of CAD.
UHC: unburned hydrocarbon; CAD: crank angle degrees; ATDC: after top dead center; RNG: renormalization group; G-RNG: generalized version of the RNG.

sec.p: The engine-out emissions are listed in Table 4. It is seen that the G-RNG model predicts lower UHC, NOx, and Soot emissions than the standard RNG model, except for CO. Unfortunately, experimental data are not available for comparison; however, the engine-out emissions for the same optical engine and condition are provided by Ekoto et al.,15,16 except that the piston does have valve cutouts. The comparisons between the predicted UHC and CO emissions and experimental data are shown in Figure 15(a) and (b), respectively. The UHC emission predicted by the G-RNG model is in better agreement with the experimental data than the prediction of standard RNG model and the results of Ekoto et al.15,16 As for the emissions of CO, the G-RNG model and the standard RNG model predict similar results. Moreover, these two models significantly improve the results of CO emissions against the previous result simulated by Ekoto et al.15,16 It be pointed out that the valve cutout effects are already considered for the current experimental data. Research of Bergin et al.29 indicated that the valve cutouts affect the engine swirl history and thus reduce the engine emissions by near 15%.

caption.p: Comparison of predicted engine-out emissions.

fn.p: RNG: renormalization group; G-RNG: generalized version of the RNG; kgf: kilograms fuel.

caption.p: Comparison of (a) UHC and (b) CO emissions. The experimental data are with a piston that has valve cutouts, whereas the simulated results are without the valve cutouts.
UHC: unburned hydrocarbon; RNG: renormalization group; G-RNG: generalized version of the RNG.

sec.p: In order to show further details of the effect of the turbulence model on the UHC, the in-cylinder contour plots of spatial UHC distributions are compared at selected timings as shown in Figure 16. Significantly improved results are obtained with new models over earlier results, which used the Han and Reitz RNG model and did not use the gas-jet model adopted in this study.15,16 It is seen that the standard RNG model also gives much better results when used with the gas-jet model, but it still predicts that a plume of UHC emerges from the piston bowl late in the expansion stroke, albeit with much reduced concentrations compared to the earlier predictions. In contrast, the UHC plume is hardly present in the present G-RNG simulation, in better agreement with the experimental data. The spatial breakdown of the UHC engine-out emissions is plotted in Figure 17. It is seen that the G-RNG model predicts lower UHC concentrations in the squish region. This is attributed to the late burning of the UHC in the expansion stroke.

caption.p: Comparison of spatial distributions of UHC between measurements and calculations at 25° ATDC (the first row) and 40° ATDC (the second row). The second column shows previous UHC predictions,15,16 while the third and fourth columns show predictions of G-RNG and standard RNG models, respectively.
CAD: crank angle degrees; ATDC: after top dead center; UHC: unburned hydrocarbon; RNG: renormalization group; G-RNG: generalized version of the RNG.
Spatial breakdown of the engine-out UHC predictions.
BW: bowl region; AB: above bowl region; SQ: squish region; UHC: unburned hydrocarbon; RNG: renormalization group; G-RNG: generalized version of the RNG.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: A generalized RNG model based on the “dimensionality” of the flow strain rate field is proposed. In this modeling approach, the turbulence model coefficients C1, C2, and C3 are constructed as functions of the flow strain rate. Computations were carried out for compressing and expanding flows in a high-speed automotive diesel engine to assess the performance of the proposed model. The analysis of the “dimensionality” of the engine flows indicates that the present generalized RNG model is more suitable than the standard RNG k−ε model. Predicted turbulence quantities were in better agreement with in-cylinder LDV measurements and were more accurate than the predictions of the standard RNG model. Especially, the trend of the modeled length scale was significantly improved during the compression stroke.

Combustion computations were also performed for the engine operating in a LTC regime, and important combustion parameters were compared and analyzed. It was found that the turbulence model affects the combustion process, especially through its effect on the turbulent viscosity. As a result, during the early stages of engine combustion, the present generalized RNG model predicted a less homogeneous mixture condition than the standard RNG k−ε model due to its lower turbulent diffusion. The result was a slower combustion rate and higher engine-out UHC. However, during the later stages of combustion, the generalized RNG model predicted increased turbulent diffusion. This increase was effective in oxidizing unburned fuel in the piston bowl region such that the predicted UHC spatial distributions agreed well with the experimental data. Thus, it is concluded that the present G-RNG model gives significantly improved predictions over previous modeling results.

ack.p: This study was supported by the Chinese Scholarship Council (CSC) and the National Key Technology Research and Development Program (2009BAG13B00) of China. The authors acknowledge the US Department of Energy Sandia National Laboratories (SNL) for supporting the project. Valuable discussions and help from Mr Yue Wang at the Engine Research Center (ERC), University of Wisconsin–Madison are also appreciated.
